column5: This year they were taking all potatoes and citrus fruit. Last year it was ALL meat, even the can of Dinty Moore stew. Do yourself a big favor and only take dry staples. Then stop at the grocery store after you cross the border. It just isn't worth the hassle of unpacking and being inspected at the border, just to save your group a whole $26.
I can't remember is there any food we can't take in? I know there are some limits.
http://www.ezbordercrossing.com/the-...hibited-items/Fresh FruitThis link lists everything you need to know. Anything with "dirt" may be prohibited. (Ex. potato)

This is from a list of What Can I Bring Into Canada. See the link below for the complete discussion. Fruits and vegetables: freshone bag up to 4 kilograms of US number 1 potatoes per person and the bag must be commercially packaged15 packages or less up to 250 kilograms of fresh fruits and vegetables per person (excluding potatoes)must be free from soil, pests, leaves, branches and/or plant debrissome restrictions on some fresh fruit and vegetables from California, Idaho, Oregon, and Washingtonin British Columbia (BC): restrictions on fresh apples, stone fruit and potatoes.http://www.beaware.gc.ca/english/brirape.shtml#a1We've never had a problem bringing fruit into Canada. We once had to dump apples on the way back into the USA, however.
We would just stop at the Safeway after we crossed the boarder and bought anything we wanted.When in doubt,buy it there.
What about Corn on the Cob? Could it meet rules if peeled?
We have never had a problem with corn on the cob.
We make our first stop at the Safeway. Nestor Falls as a nice store also.
Cheese filled weiners...we don't want any of them anywhere near here
